titlestmt.titleproper: Rockefeller University records, Lectures and Research Colloquia
A Guide to the Rockefeller University records, Lectures and Research Colloquia FA229

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2019-09-26 00:45:14 -0400.

change.item: Paper finding aid converted to EAD/XML by AureXus in 2010. Imported into the Archvists’ Toolkit by Becky Robbins.”

did.unittitle: Rockefeller University records, Lectures and Research Colloquia

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Lectures, Seminars, Research Colloquia and Thesis Presentations all form an integral part of the educational program at The Rockefeller University. Lectures which report on the work of the speaker's laboratory were one of the methods. of interchange of information among the scientists, dating from the beginnings of The Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. At that time they were called Friday afternoon lectures and were important presentations. Over the years different patterns of arrangement developed. Between 1953-1968, when Detlev Bronk was President, Alfred E. Mirsky was in charge of arranging the lectures, followed by Victor Wilson and Paul Cranefield. In the academic year 1974/1975 a committee was established with direct responsibility for programming and scheduling.
The 1974/1975 committee is composed of: Samuel C. Silverstein, Chairman, Einar Gall, Secretary, Elizabeth Dickson, Martha Fedorko, George Miller, Norton Zinder.
From their beginning, Christmas Lectures were handled by Alfred E. Mirsky under terms of a grant to him. (See Alfred E. Mirsky papers).
University Lectures and Research Colloquia are usually held on a Friday afternoon at 3:45 P.M.
Seminars are not normally arranged by the Committee on Lectures.
1973/1974, Dr. Paul Cranefield, then chairman of the Committee on Lectures instituted a plan to record, on tape, the University Lectures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of announcements (not including the Calendar of Events) starting in 1972, and audio tapes, where available, starting 1974, and some correspondence.
Box 1: Announcements/Release Forms Box 2: Audio Tapes

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Information regarding the Rockefeller Archive Center's preferred elements and forms of citation can be found at http://www.rockarch.org/research/citations.php

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: In order for a Tape to be used, permission must be obtained from the lecturer.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.
